title: Saving mining giant requires real superpowers
text:

Sun, Aug 16, 2015, 20:55 BST - UK Markets closed Saving mining giant requires real superpowers By Ben Marlow | Telegraph – 23 hours ago 72.008 0.000 
Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) has found itself in a world of pain as China cools and commodity prices tumble 
From genius to mere mortal soul. To be fair, it took something as seismic as the end of the commodities supercycle to prove his fallibility, but apparently Ivan Glasenberg isn’t superhuman or from another dimension, after all. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) wasn’t long ago that the founder of mining giant Glencore was widely lauded as a dealmaking genius when he floated the company on the London Stock Exchange. 
It was 2011, a time of huge global uncertainty, when most other business figures were focused on little more than simple self-preservation. 
Yet the suave South African chose this moment to push the button on the largest listing the City had ever seen. In one fell swoop, the commodities trader was catapulted into the upper ranks of the FTSE 100, Glasenberg joined the ranks of the super-rich thanks to a 15pc stake that saw him become a dollar-billionaire 10 times over, and its army of nearly 500 traders all made just over $100m (£64m) each. 
In the City, where huge fortunes can be made and lost in the blink of an eye, the listing was more spectacular than any ever seen, dwarfing even the bumper floats of Goldman Sachs (NYSE: GS-PB - news ) and Google (Xetra: A0B7FY - news ) in terms of wealth creation. 
The company quickly became known as “the millionaires factory”, and with good reason Glasenberg immediately earned a reputation as one of the world’s most astute business figures. 
Investors, of course, assumed they too would become rich by joining the Glencore money-making machine. 
But, unfortunately, it hasn’t quite turned out that way. 
In fact, it’s turned out pretty badly so far, thanks to a flaw in the plan: the commodities supercycle was supposed to go on for ever. Driven by seemingly limitless demand from China’s red-hot economy for every raw material on the planet, commodity prices rocketed into another stratosphere, where experts thought they would stay. 
Glencore is one of the largest producers of raw materials from iron ore to copper and aluminium, and even oil and wheat. But it is also the single biggest middleman, and therefore investors thought snapping up shares in Glencore would be a one-way bet. 
Sadly for them, it soon transpired that the supercycle turned out to be a myth and no different from previous boom-and-bust cycles. 
To compound the pain, it now seems as though Glasenberg pushed the button when at the peak. 
No one is suggesting that Glasenberg, despite his undoubted brilliance could have foreseen the forthcoming storm, but the result is that as China cools and commodity prices tumble, suddenly Glencore has found itself in a world of pain. 
As we report today, the company is battling falling profits, has a mammoth debt pile, and because it is unique in both producing and trading commodities, is more exposed to the slump than its main rivals. As a result, Glencore’s share price has fallen more than 60pc, a bigger drop than BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) , to hit an all-time low. 
To compound Glasenberg’s efforts to arrest the dramatic fall in fortunes, one of America’s biggest activist funds has suddenly turned up on his share register. No doubt the combative tycoon will dismiss the emergence of Harris (Stuttgart: HRS.SG - news ) Associates as an investor as little more than a distraction, but the hedge fund has the potential to become a big nuisance. 
At the moment, it only owns 1pc of the company’s shares but that position has doubled in recent weeks and it would not take much more of an increase for it to wield a decent amount of influence. As we’ve seen in plenty of other situations, activists don’t have to amass huge stakes for boards to capitulate. 
Glasenberg is famously feisty, so he is unlikely to easily agree to any demands he doesn’t like, but so too is David Herro, Harris Associates’ founder. 
A fascinating tussle could be brewing. 
Herro has a history of blocking deals that he thinks a company shouldn’t be attempting so perhaps he thinks Glasenberg, a serial dealmaker, could attempt another takeover as a way out of the mess. After all, it was less than a year ago that he attempted to pull off a spectacular £100bn merger with Rio Tinto. 
Given the deterioration in Glencore’s fortunes since then, it’s hard to imagine that even Glasenberg would try to revive such a massive deal, which would carry immeasurable risks. 
Instead, he should focus his efforts on turning round his company, which as things stand is going to require real superpowers. 
= Nothing like a Dane = 
FLEMMING Ornskov is another man used to pulling off deals. Since taking charge of Shire (Xetra: S7E.DE - news ) , the FTSE 100 drug-maker, just two years ago, he has taken over eight rivals. 
His next, however, may prove harder to come by. 
The Dane has launched an ambitious $30bn takeover bid for US rival Baxalta (Berlin: 9BX.BE - news ) , which makes treatments for rare diseases, but having had its offer rejected, the talks look as though they may have already reached stalemate. 
Baxalta wants a higher offer, but Shire is refusing to table one unless the Americans open the books. However, Baxalta says that can only happen if an improved bid is tabled. 
While that gives the impression that an impasse has been reached, my bet is that in the coming weeks, Ornskov deftly chips away behind the scenes, sweetens Shire’s offer slightly and eventually clinches a ninth deal.
